title: Hate crimes double in six years with transphobic abuse recording biggest rise, police figures show
text:
Hate crimes recorded by police have more than doubled to more than 100,000 in six years with transphobic abuse seeing the biggest increase, Home Office figures show.

It comes despite official crime surveys of the public showing they feel they are actually experiencing less hate, prompting claims that police are under pressure to log more crimes as having a racial, religious, sexual or transgender element.

The figures show that there were 103,379 hate crimes recorded by police this year, up 10 per cent compared with 2017/18 and double the 42,255 in 2012/13.

Three quarters of the offences (76 per cent) were recorded as race hate crimes, up by 11 per cent on last year to 78,991 and more than double the 35,845 in 2012/13.

However, the biggest increase was for transgender hate crimes which were up 37 per cent on last year to 2,333 in 2018/19. It represented a seven fold increase on 2012/13 when there were just 364 such offences.

Religious hate crimes increased by three per cent (to 8,566 offences), sexual orientation hate crimes increased 25 per cent (to 14,491) and disability hate crimes by 14 per cent (to 8,256).

However, it contrasts with the Crime Survey for England and Wales, where 50,000 people aged 16 and over are questioned about their experience of hate crime and which showed the estimated number of hate incidents had fallen by 40% in the past decade from 307,000 to 184,000.
